body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Using smart card credentials when PowerShell is running as a different user from the user currently logged in to Windows fails to fetch the certificate of Smart Card from the current user  certificate store[certmgr.msc]

The logged-in user account is different than the smart card account. 

Steps to repro:
-Launch PS 5.1 or 7 as a different user[type 2 authentication] and use the Smart card to authenticate when prompted for Windows credential, enter the pin for PSC
-connect to Azure AD or any module : for example Connect-AzureAD
-Use the UPN of the AD account that is mapped to Smart card and proceed further. Prompted to select password or pin/smart card. When selecting the latter, the certificate fails to fetch from the current user store

However, I can connect to Azure AD with the same PSC when PS is launched in elevated mode[run as Administrator] or local user account. The certificate object gets successfully detected and I get a prompt to enter Pin. 

### Expected behavior

```console
Steps to repro:
-Launch PS 5.1 or 7 as a different user[type 2 authentication] and use the Smart card to authenticate when prompted for Windows credential, enter the pin for PSC
-connect to Azure AD or any module: for example Connect-AzureAD
-Use the UPN of the AD account that is mapped to Smart card and proceed further. Prompted to select password or pin/smart card. When selecting the latter, the certificate fails to fetch from the current user store
```


### Actual behavior

```console
On selecting Certificate-based authentication, the auth prompt should fetch the certificate appropriate for the scenario and allow us to enter a pin to authenticate. In the reported scenario, the certificate request times out and throws an error No valid client certificate found
```


### Error details

```console
No valid client certificate found in the request. No valid certificates found in the user's certificate store. Please try again after closing and reopening the browser and choose a different authentication method.
```

comments.author: PaulHigin
comments.body:
@WG-Security This appears to be an external issue with the `Connect-AzureAD` azure module, which the PowerShell team does not own. The azure module handles how certificates are retrieved and the modules owners need to investigate. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/azure/active-directory/install-adv2?view=azureadps-2.0
Install AzureAD PowerShell for Graph
This provides a guide on the installation process of the Azure AD PowerShell module.

comments.author: v-kajaye
comments.body:
Hi @PaulHigin 

This is not just with Azure AD module. I noticed the same issue with MSOLS and other PS module that connect to Azure or Exchange online.

If you repro this issue with PSC with the same steps I have mentioned, someone else should also face this issue.

title: PowerShell fails to fetch Certificate object from Current user certificate store when launched as Different user
